questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with symptoms of tracheobronchitis and a persistent cough. After testing, Mycoplasma pneumoniae is identified as the causative agent. Which of the following is a notable feature of Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection that helps in its diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a characteristic "fried egg" colony appearance in blood agar culture

options.label: B
options.text: Detection of mycoplasma DNA through polymerase chain reaction (PCR)

options.label: C
options.text: High titers of cold agglutinins in the blood at 37°C

options.label: D
options.text: Indirect Coombs test detects red blood cells coated with antigens

questions.correct_answer: B. Detection of mycoplasma DNA through polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
questions.explanation:
Pulmonary Infections:

Genital Infections:

Extrapulmonary Infections:
  • Causative Agent: Mycoplasma pneumoniae (mc cause of atypical pneumonia)
  • Common Name: Primary atypical pneumonia
  • Presentation: Tracheobronchitis, Acute pharyngitis (less common), Gradual onset of fever, malaise, headache, sore throat, Persistent cough, potentially blood-tinged sputum
  • Incidence: About one-third develop pneumonia
  • Incubation Period: 1 to 3 weeks
  • Diagnosis: Radiological assessments reveal patchy consolidation in lower lobes of lungs
  • Causative Agents: Mycoplasma hominis, Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Transmission: Sexual contact
  • Conditions in Men: Urethritis, proctitis, balanoposthitis, Reiter's syndrome
  • Conditions in Women: Acute salpingitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, cervicitis, vaginitis, Infertility, abortion, postpartum fever, chorioamnionitis, low birth weight in infants

GI: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

Cardiovascular: myocarditis, pericarditis

Neurological: meningitis, encephalitis, optic neuritis

Musculoskeletal/skin: Erythema multiforme, SJS, Maculopapular/vesicular rash

Others: cold AIHA, bullous myringitis, vasculitis

Method

Description

Details

Culture

Requires specialized media and has slow growth (Option A ruled out)
  • Takes 1 to 3 weeks for visible colonies
  • Colonies have a "fried egg" appearance (In PPLO agar, with Dienes stain)
  • M. pneumoniae shows beta-hemolysis and guinea pig red blood cell agglutination

Molecular Methods

Detects mycoplasma DNA
  • PCR is used for faster and more specific detection of DNA, particularly useful for slow-growing organisms

Serology

Detects antibodies in response to Mycoplasma infection

Specific Tests:

  • Immunofluorescence, hemagglutination inhibition, growth inhibition
  • Complement fixation, indirect hemagglutination (less sensitive)

Non-Specific Tests:

  • Streptococcus MG test: Agglutination with titre of 1:20 or higher
  • Cold agglutination test: where clumping of red blood cells is observed after the mixture is incubated at 4°C and disappears upon warming to 37°C (Option C ruled out); titre of 1:32 or greater
  • Indirect Coombs test: Detects red blood cells coated with antibodies. (Option D ruled out)

Aspect

Details

Features of Mycoplasma
  • Small size, lack of cell wall, sterols in cell membrane, pleomorphic, chemoorganotrophs, ferment glucose/arginine, pass through filters, historically misclassified as viruses

Clinical Features
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia: primary atypical pneumonia, tracheobronchitis, pharyngitis, fever, malaise, headache, sore throat, persistent cough, patchy lung consolidation.
  • Genital infections: urethritis, proctitis, balanoposthitis, Reiter's syndrome (men); salpingitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, cervicitis, vaginitis, infertility, abortion, postpartum fever, chorioamnionitis, low birth weight (women)

Diagnosis
  • Culture: slow growth, "fried egg" colonies, beta-hemolysis, red blood cell agglutination.
  • Molecular: PCR for DNA
  • Serology: specific (immunofluorescence, hemagglutination inhibition, growth inhibition, complement fixation, indirect hemagglutination), non-specific (Streptococcus MG test, cold agglutination test, indirect Coombs test)

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: tetracyclines (doxycycline), macrolides (erythromycin); resistance concerns particularly with Ureaplasma strains

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and watery diarrhoea. The stool examination reveals the presence of leukocytes and blood. The patient has a history of consuming undercooked poultry. Direct microscopic examination of the stool shows darting motility of spiral rods. The laboratory report indicates that the pathogen is a Gram-negative rod that grows optimally at 42°C in microaerophilic conditions. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this infection?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Escherichia coli
  • ↳ (Option D)

Feature

Description

Morphology and Structure

Slender, spirally curved, Gram-negative rods; comma-shaped, may form 'S' or multispiral chains; non-sporing; single unsheathed polar flagellum

Growth Conditions

Microaerophilic; 5% oxygen concentration; thermophilic species grow at 42°C; strongly oxidase positive

Pathogenic Significance

Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrheal disease in developed countries

Aspect

Description

Infection Pathway

Ingestion; primary sites: jejunum and ileum; may spread to colon and rectum

Pathogenesis

Invasive pathogen; incubation period: 1-7 days; damages small intestine cells, disrupting fluid absorption

Symptoms

Fever, abdominal pain, watery diarrhea; stool may contain leukocytes and blood; typically self-limiting with possible continued shedding

Method

Description

Direct Microscopic Examination

Phase-contrast or dark field microscopy for motility; stained smears for detection of small curved rods

Culture Techniques

Plated on selective media; use transport medium if delayed; commonly used media include Skirrow's, Butzler's, Campy BAP

Incubation Conditions

42°C with 5% oxygen, 10% CO₂, 85% N₂; also at 37°C; suppresses normal fecal flora

Colony Appearance

Non-hemolytic, grey/colorless, moist, flat/convex; appears in 48 hours

Identification

Gram staining, motility, oxidase tests; biochemical tests for confirmation (positive catalase and nitrate reduction)

Treatment Type

Description

Primary Treatment

Fluid and electrolyte replacement

Antibiotic Therapy

Erythromycin is the preferred antibiotic

Method

Description

Direct Microscopic Examination

Phase-contrast or dark field microscopy for motility; stained smears for detection of small curved rods

Culture Techniques

Plated on selective media; use transport medium if delayed; commonly used media include Skirrow's, Butzler's, Campy BAP

Incubation Conditions

42°C with 5% oxygen, 10% CO₂, 85% N₂; also at 37°C; suppresses normal fecal flora

Colony Appearance

Non-hemolytic, grey/colorless, moist, flat/convex; appears in 48 hours

Identification

Gram staining, motility, oxidase tests; biochemical tests for confirmation (positive catalase and nitrate reduction)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with chronic gastritis undergoes diagnostic testing for Helicobacter pylori infection. The tests include both invasive and non-invasive methods. Which of the following non-invasive tests is specifically known for its ability to detect active H. pylori infection and provide rapid results?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Genetic Features
  • Significant genetic diversity
  • Key genes: cag (cytotoxin-associated gene), vac (vacuolating cytotoxin gene)
  • Urease production and motility contribute to pathogenesis

Clinical Manifestations
  • Asymptomatic colonization to severe gastric diseases
  • Potential outcomes: peptic ulcer disease, chronic atrophic gastritis, gastric adenocarcinoma, MALT lymphomas
  • MALT lymphomas often regress with eradication

Immune Response
  • Involves IgM, IgG, IgA production
  • Cellular immunity activation
  • Immune response does not effectively protect against infection

Invasive Diagnostic Tests
  • Endoscopic Biopsy: Tissue sample from gastric mucosa
  • Rapid Urease Test: Detects urease; results in minutes
  • Microscopy: Identifies H. pylori with staining
  • Culture: Most sensitive; involves growing bacteria; results in 3-7 days

Non-Invasive Diagnostic Tests
  • Serology (ELISA): Detects antibodies; useful for epidemiology, less reliable for active infection
  • Urea Breath Test: Detects active infection by measuring carbon dioxide from carbon-labeled urea breakdown; sensitive and reliable

Treatment
  • Standard: Bismuth subsalicylate + two antibiotics (tetracycline or amoxicillin + metronidazole) for two weeks
  • Alternative: Proton pump inhibitor (e.g., omeprazole) + clarithromycin
  • Treatment recommended for H. pylori-associated gastric or duodenal ulcers
  • Challenges: Antibiotic resistance, high recurrence rate

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with fever, non-productive cough, and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows signs of pneumonia. Suspecting Legionnaires' disease, a sputum sample is cultured on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar. Which of the following findings on BCYE agar is indicative of Legionella growth?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Characteristics

Severity

Legionnaires' Disease

Fever, non-productive cough, dyspnea, progressing to pneumonia, diarrhea, encephalopathy, causes SIADH (hyponatremia, seizures)

Causes both typical and atypical pneumonia.

Mode of infection:

  • microaspiration and aerosol inhalation
  • There is no human to human transmission

Associated with: AC, showers, coolers, cruise

Seen in : Smokers, immunocompromised patients, older patients

High (15-20% fatality)

Pontiac Fever

Mild, non-fatal symptoms: fever, chills, myalgia, headache

Mild

Method

Sample Type

Notes

Direct Fluorescent Antibody (DFA)

Sputum, bronchial aspirate, lung biopsy

Detects Legionella in specimens

Culture

Clinical specimens
  • Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) Agar- Gold standard for Legionella culture; contains yeast extract, iron, L-cysteine, and charcoal; optimal pH ~6.9
  • Small colonies, often grayish or black, due to iron reduction by bacteria. (Option C)
  • L-cysteine Presence: Required for growth, confirming presumptive Legionella colonies.

Antigen Detection in Urine

Urine

Latex agglutination or ELISA

Serum Antibody Detection

Blood

ELISA or indirect immunofluorescence

Category

Details

Features

Thin, Gram-negative, non-capsulated bacilli (2-5 x 0.1-0.3 µm); Poor Gram staining, best visualized by DFA; Requires BCYE agar for growth

Clinical Features

Legionnaires' Disease: Fever, non-productive cough, dyspnea, pneumonia, diarrhea, encephalopathy (15-20% fatality)

Pontiac Fever: Mild symptoms (fever, chills, myalgia, headache), non-fatal

Diagnosis Methods

DFA: Detects Legionella in sputum, bronchial aspirate, lung biopsy

Culture: Gold standard using BCYE agar (small, grayish/black colonies due to iron reduction)

Urine Antigen: Latex agglutination or ELISA

Serum Antibody: ELISA or indirect immunofluorescence

Treatment

First-line: Macrolides, ciprofloxacin, tetracyclines

Severe cases: Rifampicin (added if needed)

Ineffective: Beta-lactamase antibiotics, aminoglycosides

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying Klebsiella pneumoniae and its microscopic characteristics. Which of the following statements about the microscopy of Klebsiella pneumoniae is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is Gram-positive and appears purple under Gram staining

options.label: B
options.text: Its capsule is visible using the Warthin-Starry method.

options.label: C
options.text: They are observed as elongated, slender rods that are encapsulated

options.label: D
options.text: There is an absence of biofilm when examined with a scanning electron microscope (SEM).

questions.correct_answer: B. Its capsule is visible using the Warthin-Starry method.
questions.explanation:
Features
  • Non-motile, capsulated, short, plump rods (1-2 µm x 0.5-1.8 µm).
  • Common as intestinal commensals and saprophytes in soil and water.
  • Ferment glucose, lactose, sucrose, and mannitol, producing acid and gas

Clinical Features

Major healthcare-associated pathogen, commonly causing:

  • Pneumonia (upper lobe pneumonia): Severe, often affecting middle-aged/older adults with risk factors (e.g., alcoholism, diabetes).
  • UTIs, particularly catheter-associated (CAUTI).
  • Lung abscess, red current jelly sputum, bulging fissure sign
  • Neonatal sepsis: High mortality due to multidrug resistance.
  • Septicemia and other pyogenic infections.

Morphological Characteristics
  • Appears as short, plump, encapsulated rods with visible halos in Gram-stained smears. (Option C ruled out)

Gram Staining
  • Gram-negative; appears pink after counterstaining with safranin. (Option A ruled out)
  • Typically rod-shaped (bacilli).

Capsule Visualization
  • Encapsulation visualized using staining techniques (e.g., Warthin-Starry method, India ink preparation), highlighting the polysaccharide capsule, crucial for evading phagocytosis.

Fluorescence Microscopy
  • Used to assess antibiotic efficacy (e.g., meropenem) and monitor morphological changes post-treatment, showing enlarged or distorted cells.

Biofilm Structure
  • Studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to visualize complex biofilm architecture, essential for understanding bacterial adherence and interaction with surfaces. (Option D ruled out)

Biochemical tests:

Treatment

Empiric therapy for bloodstream infections often needed:

  • Options include piperacillin-tazobactam, cefoperazone-sulbactam, or amikacin.
  • Carbapenems (imipenem, meropenem) are preferred for resistant or critical cases.

Aspect

Description

Common Infections

Pneumonia, UTIs, septicemia, neonatal sepsis, pyogenic infections

High-Risk Groups

Middle-aged/older adults with comorbidities (alcoholism, diabetes), neonates, ICU patients

Mortality Factors

High for pneumonia and neonatal sepsis, often due to multidrug-resistant strains

Infection Type

Initial Empiric Treatment

Resistant/Critical Cases Treatment

Bloodstream Infections

Piperacillin-tazobactam, cefoperazone-sulbactam, amikacin

Carbapenems (imipenem, meropenem)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of Francisella tularensis infection (tularemia) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Culturing F. tularensis is easily performed on standard blood agar.

options.label: B
options.text: Serological tests are always reliable and do not require confirmation with other diagnostic methods

options.label: C
options.text: Direct microscopy of patient samples is the primary method for diagnosis

options.label: D
options.text: Isolation of the organism from clinical specimens is essential for confirming tularemia

questions.correct_answer: D. Isolation of the organism from clinical specimens is essential for confirming tularemia
questions.explanation:
Method

Description

Culture

Requires specialized media (e.g., Francis’ blood dextrose cystine agar); small transparent colonies appear after 3-5 days of incubation. (Option A ruled out)

Animal Inoculation

Identified by inoculating guinea pigs or mice with patient samples.

Serology

Detection of agglutinating antibodies in patient sera. Can yield false negatives and therefore require further confirmation with cultures.(Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Match the following features/diseases with their respective organisms: 1. Klebsiella pneumoniae a. Chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of nose 2. Klebsiella ozaenae b. Foul-smelling nasal discharge 3. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis c. Healthcare-associated infections, UTI, septicemia
questions.explanation:
1. Klebsiella pneumoniae

c. Healthcare-associated infections, UTI, septicemia

2. Klebsiella ozaenae

b. Foul-smelling nasal discharge

3. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

a. Chronic granulomatous hypertrophy of nose
